item.title: Winter Holidays, University Closed (12/25/2017 - 1/2/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 12/25/2017
End Date: 1/2/2018 End Time: Midnight
UHD will be closed for winter holidays from December 25, 2017 until January 2, 2018. We will re-open for business on Wednesday, January 3, 2018.

item.title: Best Practices of Video Integration in Online & Hybrid Courses
item.description: This workshop is designed to help you use video more effectively in your online and hybrid classes. This session focuses on strategies to enhance instructor presence, engage students, and increase perceptions of enjoyment and learning. You will also learn the technical aspects of recording and sharing video with your students.

item.title: Blackboard Open Lab: Ready for Spring 2018
item.description: Come to this open lab and get help and tips from our team of Blackboard experts. This workshop will provide a space for you to ask questions about things like course copy, tests, and grades. No registration required.

item.title: Jim McIngvale "Mattress Mack" awarded Social Work Program 2017 Person of the Year
item.description:
On Thursday, January 25th at 5:30 p.m. here in the College of Public Service , the Social Work Program has the distinct honor of awarding their Person of the Year award to Houston's own Jim McIngvale of Gallery Furniture. It was in 1981 that Mr. McIngvale, otherwise known as Mattress Mack, and his wife Linda, started Gallery Furniture with five thousand dollars and a dream. Mack began television advertising early on and with his motto of Early to bed, early to rise, work like hell and advertise, he quickly became a household name. If you live in Houston you've no doubt heard of Mr. McIngvale's generosity. During Hurricane Harvey, Mack sheltered many Houstonians in the Gallery Furniture facility. In fact, some of our very own faculty were assisted. Please join us at 5:30 p.m. on Thursday, January 25 as we honor Jim McIngavle as the 2017 UHD Social Work Person of the Year.
Some of Mack's charitable contributions include:
Co-founded the Peace of Mind Foundation for those affected by Obsessive Compulsive Disorder Funded St. Luke's Mobile Stroke Unit Large contributor to Texas Heart Institute, Baylor College of Medicine and Harvard Medical School Instrumental in getting Menninger Clinic to move to Houston to provide mental health care to Houston by providing a multi-million dollar donation Fed 25,000 people Thanksgiving dinner for several years Annual Christmas give-away furnishing hundreds of housefuls of furniture for the past 30 years Bought 10,000 toys for needy children, distributed during the holiday One of the largest contributors to the Houston Livestock Show & Rodeo with over $4 million given Helped start and continuously fund the KickStart Kids Program in Houston Furnished USO facilities around the world Hosted events for and donated to the Salvation Army Donated thousands of dollars of furniture to hundreds of teacher lounges in Houston area schools Helped to raise over $12 million dollars for the Bush/Clinton fund to aid those affected by the Tsunami in Southeast Asia and Hurricanes Katrina and Rita Underwrote YMCA playground at Reliant Stadium for Katrina Evacuees and housed several hundred evacuees during hurricane crisis Underwrote National OCF Conference held in Houston Recipient of Mental Health Association Award in 2005 Donated tennis racquets to inner city kids that would not otherwise have the opportunity to take tennis lessons

item.title: 6th Biannual Forum on Plain English at UHD
item.description:
We are pleased to invite you to participate in the sixth biannual Forum on Plain English organized by the Institute for Plain English Research and Study at UHD. The forum will be held at the University of Houston-Downtown, on February 9 , 2018.
The forum aims to promote informed uses of Plain English guidelines, which are writing standards recommended by several government agencies for improved communications with the general public.
Keynote Speaker: Leslie O’Flahavan is owner of E-WRITE, the writing training company she formed in 1996. Leslie is a plain language practitioner who helps customer care organizations for some of the world’s biggest brands write better email, chat, and social media to customers. She’s a customer service writing expert who can teach the most stubborn, inexperienced, or word-phobic frontline employees to improve their writing skills, so they can do their jobs better. As a result of her work, E-WRITE clients improve their customer satisfaction ratings, reduce training cycles, improve productivity, and limit legal risk. Leslie’s recent projects include helping Marriott launch live chat for their Sales IT Support team, training Air Canada’s 150+ Customer Relations agents to write in the airline’s updated brand voice, and writing a Social Media Guidebook for Hawaiian Airlines’ Reservations team. She’s helped thousands of employees apply plain language principles to their everyday work.
Our one-day forum will address the following topics: • Customer Service Writing: Why Companies Should Use Plain Language in Emails, Chats, and Tweets to Customers • Seven Plain Language Practices That Will Release the Hot Air from Your Writing
See the attached flyer for details.
Registration deadline: Monday, February 5, 2018 Seating is limited. Register for the forum using our online registration:
http://uhd.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_egSqVrr2gYdxKf3.
Please provide your working email address so that we could contact you with parking instructions and campus maps.https://calendar.uhd.edu/displaymedia.aspx?whatToDo=attch&id=533" title="Event program

Runtime: 2h 19min Get Out @ 1:45 pm - It's time for a young African-American to meet with his white girlfriend's parents for a weekend in their secluded estate in the woods, but before long, the friendly and polite ambiance will give way to a nightmare. Runtime: 1h 44min Moonlight @ 3:45 - A chronicle of the childhood, adolescence and burgeoning adulthood of a young, African-American, gay man growing up in a rough neighborhood of Miami. Runtime 1h 51min
Popcorn and refreshments provided!

item.title: Free Webinar: Integrating iClicker Cloud and LMS Gradebooks
item.description:
Would you like to learn more about integrating your iClicker grades into your LMS gradebook? Do you use Blackboard, Canvas, Brightspace by D2L, or Sakai as a learning management system? iClicker Cloud offers two options for integrating with your LMS: single-column grade sync and multiple-column grade sync
Join us on Tuesday, February 13th from 2:30 ET - 3:15 ET for an overview of these integration options, hosted by our Customer Integrations Specialist, Brian Krutzel, and our Client Services Manager, Chad Moeller. They will dig into how each integration is executed by campus administrators, instructors, and students. Natalie Dougall, Faculty Consultant and iClicker Trainer, will also discuss different pedagogical approaches to the grading process.

item.title: Resolving the Breadth-depth-inquiry Dilemma in College Science Courses
item.description:
Event Description: Instructors of introductory science courses constantly face the dilemma of how to balance the coverage of diverse topics versus an in-depth treatment of key concepts, or spending time helping students learn how to do problem solving and scientific inquiry. We deploy a suite of approaches and assessment tools that allow us to simultaneously address these three competing aspects of breadth, depth, and inquiry. To address a breadth of topics, we provide students with a What-to-Know List, and students are responsible for each item, even if that subject is not covered in lecture. This breadth of knowledge is assessed by weekly, online multiple-choice quizzes derived from items on the WTK List.
To assess deep knowledge, we provide students with a list of 12 possible concept-sketch questions for the next exam . For each exam, we display two or three concept-sketch questions from the list, and students answer two questions, drawing and explaining each concept sketch on one side of the paper. Properly answering a concept-sketch question requires students to ahead of time develop complete answers &mdash; and therefore gain deep knowledge. For smaller classes, students are required to answer each concept-sketch question or item on the WTK List in a composition-book-sized portfolio that is collected and quickly graded for each exam. Use of these portfolios has dramatically increased student understanding and grades.
To assess inquiry skills, students complete each of the chapter-ending Investigations from the textbook, either online or on paper worksheets done in class and in small groups. Using this overall three-pronged approach, students are exposed to and assessed on a broad range of topics, but also need to have in-depth knowledge of 48 key topics. Freed from the requirement that we cover every topic during lectures, class time includes more active learning and time to develop problem-solving and inquiry skills, resolving the breadth-depth-inquiry dilemma. Presenter Information : Dr. Stephen J. Reynolds received degrees in geosciences from University of Texas at El Paso and University of Arizona. He directed the geologic mapping program of the Arizona Geological Survey, where he produced a new geologic map of Arizona. He currently is a professor in the School of Earth and Space Exploration at Arizona State University, where he does research on cognition and learning, natural resources, and evolution of Southwestern landscapes. He has authored or edited over 200 maps, articles, and reports, ranging from tectonics to climate. He is the author of popular, award-winning textbooks, including Exploring Geology, Exploring Physical Geography, Exploring Earth Science, and Structural Geology of Rocks and Regions. He was President of the Arizona Geological Society and received outstanding alumni awards from UTEP and the University of Arizona. Julia K. Johnson is a full-time faculty member in the School of Earth and Space Exploration at ASU. Her research involves geoscience education, structural geology, and regional geology. The main focus of her geoscience education research is on student- and instructor-generated sketches for learning, teaching, and assessment in college geology classes. At ASU, she teaches Introduction to Geology to more than 2,000 students per year in in-person and online classes. Julia is recognized as one of the best science teachers at ASU, and has received student-nominated teaching awards and very high teaching evaluations in spite of her challenging classes. She gives talks and webinars to faculty members across the county about how to redesign their own classes to improve efficiency and student performance at the same time. Julia is coauthor of the Exploring Geology, Exploring Earth Science, and Exploring Physical Geography textbooks, Observing and Interpreting Geology , and publications on geology and science-education research, including an article in the Journal of Geoscience Education on concept sketches.
Room: N-602 . Contact Dr. Heinlein with any questions!

item.title: School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline?
item.description:
School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline?
Presented Dr. Augustina Reyes
This talk will explore school discipline data to show that the way children are treated in school can help to set them on a path for later in life. Students who are suspended in school are more likely to be arrested than students who are never suspended. Join us in following the school-to-prison pipeline from state policy to district policy to school leadership practices to the detention center.
Followed by refreshments and a Q&A with Dr. Reyes
For more information contact: Steven Villano at villanos@uhd.edu

item.title: Documentary Film Screening - Black America Since MLK: And Still I Rise
item.description: Discussion Facilitated by Dr. Jonathan Chism, Assistant Professor of History This film explores the last five decades of black history since the civil rights era and the death of Martin Luther King Jr. Narrated by the esteemed Henry Louis Gates Jr., the film encourages deep reflection on questions such as: How far have we come toward racial equality since the civil rights era? What does it mean to be black today? How have we, as a nation, elected a black President while events like those in Ferguson continue to occur?​

item.description: A disturbing expose of sexual assaults on American college campuses, their institutional cover-ups, and the devastating toll they take on students and their families. item.title: Film Screening & Discussion - The Mask You Live In
item.description: This film follows boys and young men as they struggle to stay true to themselves while negotiating America's limited definition of masculinity. Pressured by the media, their peer groups, and even the adults in their lives, these young men confront messages encouraging them to disconnect from their emotions, to devalue authentic friendships, to objectify women, and to resolve conflicts through violence. These gender stereotypes interconnect with race, class, and circumstance, creating a maze of identity issues boys and young men must navigate to become "REAL" men.

item.title: Help Yourself, Help a Friend: Suicide Prevention & Intervention

Join us for a thoughtful film experience that will lead to a lively discussion.

item.title: Building Gator Grit: Cultivating Positive Learning Environments to Enhance Motivation for Diverse Le
item.description:
Building Gator Grit: Cultivating Positive Learning Environments to Enhance Motivation for Diverse Learners
Session Description: Grit, resilience, mindset attitudes and beliefs that signal intrinsic motivation have recently become widely recognized in popular culture as important ingredients of success. However, research on the relationship between intrinsic motivation and academic success goes back many decades. Much is known about the value and practice of fostering motivation among diverse learners . This workshop provides a foundation for faculty and staff to reflect on how our own mindset influences how we think about students and offers alternative practices in order to create positive learning environments. Grounded in culturally responsive pedagogy, the workshop will help participants develop a deeper understanding of the connections between student development, motivation, engaged learning, and culture. It helps answer two important, related questions: How might my practices be reframed to foster a learning environment which establishes inclusion, develops positive attitudes, and engenders competence? And, how can I as an individual faculty or staff contribute to increased enrollment and student persistence?
Facilitator: Jonathan Grant Brown, Program Manager, AVID for Higher Education, http://www.avid.org/speakers-bureau.ashx
Location A-627, please register by March 21

item.title: Film Screening & Discussion - The Mask You Live In
item.description: This film follows boys and young men as they struggle to stay true to themselves while negotiating America's limited definition of masculinity. Pressured by the media, their peer groups, and event the adults in their lives, these young men confront messages encouraging them to disconnect from their emotions, to devalue authentic friendships, to objectify women, and to resolve conflicts through violence. These gender stereotypes interconnect with race, class, and circumstance, creating a maze of identity issues boys and young men must navigate to become "REAL" men.

item.title: Scholarly and Creative Activities Showcase
item.description:
College of Public Service faculty who have been awarded internal funding initiatives to support innovative projects in curriculum, research, service, and community partnerships will present at this showcase of scholarly and creative activities. Guests are invited to participate in a roundtable discuss with faculty who will share insights about their work from conception of the idea, to development of the proposal, to the execution of the project.
Featured Faculty and their Projects Include:
Dr. Franklin Allaire, Exploring teacher Identity Construction and Negotiation: A Longitudinal Study Dr. Beth Gilmore, Police Views on Policing Dr. Angie Goins, Geriatric Social Work Education: A Historical Perspective on the Social Response to Aging Dr. Heather Goltz, Pap Testing Among Older Adults, also, highlighting a case study of Sexual and Gender Minorities Who are Bladder Cancer Survivors Drs. Laura Mitchell and Jackie Sack, Co-Teaching Learning Environment: Pre-Service Bilingual Generalists Explore Their Language and Math Identities in a Required Math Methods Course

item.title: Helena Maria Viramontes:A Reading and Book Signing
item.description:
Novelist Helena Maria Viramontes is a major figure in American and Mexican American Literature, who is particularly important in developments in Chicana feminism from the 1980s forward. Named a USA Ford Fellow in Literature for 2007, she has received numerous awards, including the John Dos Passos Prize for literature.
Author of Under the Feet of Jesus, The Moths and Other Stories, and Their Dogs Came with Them, Viramontes is currently Professor of Creative Writing at Cornell University.

item.title: Retention Center: Student Success
item.description: The Retention Center provides an easy way for you to discover which students in your course are at risk. Based on preconfigured rules and rules you create, students' engagement and participation are visually displayed, quickly alerting you to potential risk. From the Retention Center, you can communicate with struggling students and help them take immediate action for improvement. You can begin using the Retention Center features immediately&mdash;no setup required.

item.title: First-Year Student Success: Teaching Time Management & Behavioral Change
item.description:
First-Year Student Success: Teaching Time Management & Behavioral Change Lunch & Learn Event: Webinar Viewing & Discussion Thursday, April 5, 2018, 11:45am to 1:15pm Join your colleagues as we view and discuss the ideas presented in the webinar below. Lunch will be served. Please reserve your seat before Monday, April 2. Attendance is limited to 20 registrants. Session description: Researchers argue that self-regulatory behaviors are at the heart college success. In fact, studies indicate that the ability to manage time and combat procrastination is more predictive of college achievement than standardized tests and high school grades. Unfortunately, many undergraduate students enter post-secondary institutions without having mastered the basic study skills and self-regulatory behaviors that foster college success. The inability to master these behavioral and cognitive skill sets contributes to negative outcomes ranging from compromised immune systems to damaged relationships to impeded academic performance. This webinar explores self-regulatory behaviors from several theoretical frameworks and provides participants with practical strategies and tools to get even their most-at-risk students to break the cycle of procrastination and move toward behavior change. Session outcomes: -Examine basic research findings -Explore behavior change model -Critique & understand flaws in current time management pedagogy -Identify psychodynamics of procrastination from different theoretical frameworks -Analyze & understand the cycle of procrastination -Improve strategies for helping your students combat procrastination -Discover tips to implement effective pedagogical tools immediately
For more info, contact Dr. Bill Waller (mailto:wallerw@uhd.edu / 713.221.8404
Room TBD.

item.title: The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Sucess in the K-12 Context
item.description:
'The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Sucess in the K-12 Context Lecture'
The University of Houston-Downtown College of Public Service and the Department of Minority Male Recruitment will be presenting the, 'The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Success in the K-12 Context Lecture', featuring author and scholar, Dr. Gilman Whiting, Director of the Scholar Identity Institute, and Associate Professor of the African-American and Diaspora Studies and Callie House Research Center at Vanderbilt University
Date: Monday, April 9, 2018 Address: Commerce Building, 1002 Commerce Street, Houston, TX 77002 Room Location: Commerce -C100
Lecture #1: 3:30pm-5:00pm –Community leaders, faculty and staff
Lecture #2: 5:30pm-7:00pm –Student session only
Dr. Gilman W. Whiting is an Associate Professor of African American and Diaspora Studies and Director of Graduate Studies. His areas of research include: race, sports, and American culture; educational disparity; welfare reform and fatherhood initiatives; special and gifted education. He has authored over forty scholarly articles in journals such as Roeper Review, Journal for Secondary Gifted Education, and The International Journal of Sport and Society, and book chapters. Dr. Whiting is the creator of the Scholar Identity Model™ and consults with school districts nationally and internationally. He is also the founding chair of the Achievement Gap Institute for the Peabody College of Education.
Please follow the link below to RSVP
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-scholar-identity-model-black-male-success-in-the-k-12-context-tickets-44454616956?utm-medium=discovery&utm-campaign=social&utm-content=attendeeshare&aff=escb&utm-source=cp&utm-term=listing

item.title: HIPs & Community Engagement Showcase
item.description:
The Center for Teaching and Learning Excellence and Center for Community Engagement and Service Learning call for proposals from UHD faculty , staff , and students interested in presenting their work at the UHD HIPs and Community Engagement Showcase to be held April 10, 2018 from 8:00 am to 3:30 pm in The Welcome Center . Faculty and staff presentations should be focused on approaches to implementing High-Impact Practices , Service Learning , or Community Engagement in curricular or co-curricular settings. Students are encouraged to co-present with faculty and staff or present their projects done in SL-designated courses or through CE grants. Applicants are not required to have a CTLE or CCESL-funded project to present at the showcase but those with currently or previously funded projects are strongly encouraged to present.
Proposal Submission Process:
o Your name, affiliation, email, and names/info. for each co-presenter o Format of presentation 11:30 am-12:45 pm Poster presentations 2:30-3:30 pm Round-Table Quick Talks - 10 minutes repeated 3-5 times at a table of 4-6 participants Call for Proposals: https://tinyurl.com/hipsceshowcase2018
Questions or x8280.

item.title: The Sustainability Initiative Student Proposals
item.description:
UHD's Center for Urban Agriculture and Sustainability has the vision of providing Houston citizens with the knowledge and resources to build sustainable neighborhoods throughout the city. CUAS is committed to developing sustainable solutions and raising student awareness in order to create stable urban ecosystems, reduce carbon emissions and increase urban food production. The Sustainability Initiative was created so that UHD students can carry out their own sustainability projects.
This initiative originated from a student government proposal for a sustainability tax to be added to student fees. The tax could be used to fund student projects that would improve the sustainability of UHD or the surrounding region. In lieu of this tax, the UHD Administration has agreed to fund this student initiative for two years to determine if there is student interest in self-directed sustainability projects.
Proposal Focus The focus of the proposal can be any project that will promote sustainability practices at UHD or the greater Houston community. Projects are welcome from enrolled students in all colleges of the university and may focus on subjects such as educational campaigns, small business consulting, green initiatives, new technologies or new UHD resources such as new UHD infrastructure, art or digital materials. Benefits of Applying for this Initiative
A student or group of students can design a project that creates or builds on sustainable practices within UHD or the larger Houston community. Students will gain experience running an independent project and make valuable connections to the community or industry. Funds will be made available for students to carry out the project.
https://www.uhd.edu/academics/sciences/center-for-urban-agriculture-and-sustainability/Documents/SustainabilityInitiativeApplication.pdf

item.title: UHD 64th Commencement
item.description:
Join us in congratulating the spring class of 2018.
UHD 64th Commencement Saturday, May 26, 2018 Minute Maid Park 11:00 a.m.
https://www.uhd.edu/commencement/

item.title: Tone Dance Fusion
item.description: Experience an all in one experience. This class combines a warm up, 20 minutes of strength training, 20 minutes of cardio dance, and ends with a cool down and mindfulness session. This class will give you a full body and mind workout.

item.title: MBA Information Session
item.description:
Join us for an Information Session to learn more about the UHD MBA. You'll hear about admissions requirements, meet faculty and administrators, view the curriculum and learn what makes the UHD MBA unique.
Learn more and register on our https://www.uhd.edu/academics/business/mba/admissions/Pages/info-sessions.aspx page.

item.description:

have one-on-one admissions counseling learn about scholarships and financial aid submit documentation for expedited processing and much more!

item.title: Assessment of Education Programs
item.description: With the exception of the General Education and Developmental Education programs, program faculty submit the annual assessment report to the department chair or dean by October 30 of the academic year following the year in which the work was assessed.
